comment.body: You can use `ionice` if you want to limit IO. I would prefer not to slow it down when I just want it to run as fast as possible. Could be add a command line option to limit the IO?

pull_request.title: feat: add verify option for transmission-show
feat: add verify option for transmission-show
feat: add verify option for transmission-show
feat: add verify option for transmission-show

comment.body:
> In this case the user expects the verify to run as quick as possible

True, but as a user, I'd appreciate it if Transmission does not starve my other IO-intensive applications, or cause an overall slowdown in any way. So I think it's better to revert this change.

pull_request.title: feat: add verify option for transmission-show
feat: add verify option for transmission-show

issue.title: feat: add verify option for transmission-show

comment.body: The remaining comments look straightforward and I will work on them sometime in the next few days.

pull_request.title: feat: add verify option for transmission-show

comment.body: When there are errors `verify_callback()` can be called multiple times per file. eg Multiple failed pieces in the one file. I could make it one callback per file with a vector of errors but it makes the `verify_torrent()` logic more complicated. It doesn't help that a piece can contain multiple files.

pull_request.title: feat: add verify option for transmission-show
feat: add verify option for transmission-show

comment.body: That is a good idea. My intention is to report the errors as accurately as possible.

pull_request.title: feat: add verify option for transmission-show

comment.body:
My understanding of that comment is that when running a session with other torrents downloading, you want to ensure the verify does not slow down the other torrents. The change I am adding is for a command line utility that runs in a single thread with no other IO. In this case the user expects the verify to run as quick as possible, similar to running other IO intensive utils like `cp` or `tar`.

I intended to pass `sleep_ms_per_second` to `sleep_for()`. That was a mistake.

pull_request.title: feat: add verify option for transmission-show
feat: add verify option for transmission-show
feat: add verify option for transmission-show

comment.body:
Please correct me if I am wrong here.

AFAICT, `verify_callback()` is called at most once for each file, so this if condition isn't needed. In fact, this is causing the last file to *not* be printed, which you worked around by repeating code inside `verify()`, so there's a very good reason to remove it.

Following the same logic, we can also do away with `verify_cb::errors` because each file will have at most 1 error getting printed out. `verify_callback()` can probably be drastically simplified after this change.

pull_request.title: feat: add verify option for transmission-show

review.body: @srussel I think that's all the comments I have for now. Thank you for writing this!

pull_request.title: feat: add verify option for transmission-show

review.body: @srussel I think that's all the comments I have for now. Thank you for writing this!

pull_request.title: feat: add verify option for transmission-show

issue.title: Availability fluctuates
issue.body:
### What is the issue?

Availability fluctuates between 83.1 and 83.2% on a torrent where only one other peer is reachable. Neither of us has 83.1 or 83.2% downloaded, we both down- and upload to/from each other.

Small bug but a bug nonetheless.

### Which application of Transmission?

Qt app on Windows

### Which version of Transmission?

4.0.2

comment.body:
transmission does not initialize, crashes!
the problem appears to occur in this code update and the previous one.
I'm using Windows 11 x64, and the latest version (includes this commit).

I don't know how I can contribute to sending an error log, as transmission doesn't show an error, it just shows a blank window for 1 second and closes.

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -50,3 +50,6 @@
 [submodule "third-party/small"]
 	path = third-party/small
 	url = https://github.com/transmission/small.git
+[submodule "third-party/rapidjson"]
+	path = third-party/rapidjson
+	url = https://github.com/transmission/rapidjson.git
comment.body: Nevermind I got confused, it does work.

pull_request.title: refactor: drop jsonsl in favour of RapidJSON
pull_request.body:
Fixes #4177.

This PR does the bare minimum to drop jsonsl in favour of RapidJSON.

#### Benifits
- No more headache for dealing with UTF, escaping, locale and whatnot
- Drastically fewer lines of code thanks to the previous point
- The library is more actively maintained

#### Drawbacks
- No more in-place parsing for JSON, since RapidJSON can either "copy all strings" or "modify the source string when unescaping", but it cannot "copy only strings that needs unescaping".

I am still figuring out if we can use even more of the library, for example:
- We might be able to replace the functionalities of `tr_variant` with `rapidjson::Document`.
- We might be able to replace the functionalities of utfcpp with `rapidjson::Transcoder`.

Notes: Dropped jsonsl in favour of RapidJSON as our json lexer.

labels.name: type:refactor
labels.description: A code change that neither fixes a bug nor adds a feature

labels.name: semver:minor
labels.description: adds functionality in a backwards compatible manner

pull_request.title: fix: remove `fetchRecurseSubmodules = false` from RapidJSON submodule

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -50,3 +50,6 @@
 [submodule "third-party/small"]
 	path = third-party/small
 	url = https://github.com/transmission/small.git
+[submodule "third-party/rapidjson"]
+	path = third-party/rapidjson
+	url = https://github.com/transmission/rapidjson.git
comment.body:
I don't think `fetchRecurseSubmodules = false` is working the way we want.

`git clone --recurse-submodules` does not pull RapidJSON, and `git submodule update --init --recursive` pulls the nested gtest anyways.

I will create a PR to remove this config.
